description: Borrowed from Latin vindicātus, perfect passive participle of vindicō (“lay legal claim to something; set free; protect, avenge, punish”), from vim, accusative singular of vīs (“force, power”), + dīcō (“say; declare, state”). See avenge.

verbs.description: vindicate (third-person singular simple present vindicates, present participle vindicating, simple past and past participle vindicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To clear of an accusation, suspicion or criticism.

examples: to vindicate a right, claim or title

entries.meaning: (transitive) To maintain or defend (a cause) against opposition.
examples: to vindicate the rights of labor movement in developing countries
The violent history of the suspect vindicated the use of force by the police.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lay claim to; to assert a right to; to claim.
(transitive, obsolete) To liberate; to set free; to deliver.
